Operations personnel make regular inspections of the equipment and processes they operate.  If something out of the ordinary is found, it is reported to management in order to expediently resolve any problems.

The engineering and administrative controls in place have been established to reduce the risk of an accidental release of identified hazardous materials.  Enterprise is committed to operations that are safe for employees and the surrounding community.

Accident History

Based on the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10, this facility has not had any accidental release in the past 5 years.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The following is a list of improvements that have either been recently completed or are planned for implementation at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases: 

* The written PSM management system is presently undergoing a complete review and revision to provide an updated program which complies with the requirements of the PSM Standard and can be fully implemented at the diverse number of facilities in the Enterprise partnership. 
* As a follow-up to a detailed facility siting overpressure study, the Chaco Plant office was recently reinforced on two exposed surfaces through the installation of a brick blast pressure deflection wall.
* Also in response to the facilty siting study, the plant operations control room is currently being relocated from a separate building near the process area to a more robustly designed area inside the plant office building.

Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Plan
Enterprise Chaco Cryogenic Plant
RMP Executive Summary

At Enterprise Chaco Cryogenic Plant, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those handling hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help provide for the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.   

The Chaco Cryogenic Plant is owned by Enterprise Field Services LLC, and is operated by Enterprise Products Operating LLC.

This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that have been designed and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances required by EPA's RMP regulation and the processes involved.
* A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases.
* Emergency Response Programs.
* General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps.
* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals at the Chaco Cryogenic Plant that are regulated by EPA's RMP rule.  

Facility Description

The Chaco Cryogenic Plant consists of two cryogenic gas processing trains which process gas from the surrounding gas field and remove recoverable natural gas liquids from the raw field gas.  This is accomplished by changes in the temperature and pressure of the inlet natural gas stream which causes the liquids to condense out of the natural gas stream.  The condensed NGL is treated to remove Carbon Dioxide, dehydrated and then shipped via pipeline to Mont Belvieu Texas for fractionation.  The residue gas stream is re-compressed and shipped via pipeline to distribution by others.

In our process we use the following chemicals/flammables that the EPA has identified as having the potentia

l to cause significant offsite consequence in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Toxics

No toxic materials to report.

Flammables

Natural Gas Liquid and Refrigerant Propane are the only flammable substances that are maintained in a quantity above the threshold quantities listed in 40 CFR 68.115. 

Key Offsite Consequence Analysis Scenarios

The EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case scenarios(s) and alternative release scenario(s) for our facility.  

Worst/Alternate Case Release Scenarios Regulated Toxic Chemical

At the present time there are no regulated toxic chemicals to report for the Chaco Plant.  

Worse/Alternate Case Scenarios Regulated Flammable Chemicals

The worst case scenario for the Chaco Cryogenic Plant involves the amount of flammable mixture that would be released if the larger of the two deethanized product surge tanks is full and suffers a catastrophic failure and release.  The details of the offsite consequence analysis will not be reflected in the executive summary but rather is reflected in the data components of the RMP.  There are no receptors in the Worst Case Scenario distance, so the facility is eligible and is being registered as an RMP Program 1 facility.

Emergency Response Program

Enterprise Chaco Plant maintains an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) in compliance with local emergency response agencies.  Chaco Plant's Emergency Shutdown System (ESD) has been designed to provide a means to rapidly shutdown the total plant and to quickly put the facility in a safe condition in order to minimize the possibility of a catastrophic occurrence.  The ESD System performs three important functions: 1) It deactivates equipment in the area 2) It blocks gas and other combustible material from entering the area 3) It vents, either automatically or manually,  the contained combustible products to a remote, safe location or flare stack.  The ESD system can be initiated manually at

nine strategically located ESD Pull Switches. Additionally parts of the process will automatically shutdown equipment when unsafe operating conditions are detected.  The facility also has strategically installed hazardous gas monitoring and fire eye detection systems which are tied into the ESD system.

In the event of an accidental release, the facility operators are trained to isolate any fuel source from a safe location or activate one of the shutdown devices, contact 9-1-1, evacuate personnel and secure the area.  The ERP is reviewed with Chaco Plant employees at least annually or when any changes are made to the ERP.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Enterprise takes a systematic, protective approach to preventing accidental release of hazardous chemicals.  Our Process Safety Management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention program, including:

* Process safety information
* Process hazard analysis
* Operating procedures
* Training
* Mechanical integrity
* Management of change
* Pre-Startup Safety Review - PSSR
* Compliance audits
* Incident investigation
* Employee participation
* Hot work permit
* Contractors

As a part of the prevention efforts, there are several programs in which Enterprise employees participate.  A training program has been developed in which Operations and Maintenance personnel are specifically trained in the operation of the facility, the operating procedures, maintenance procedures, and specific other regulations and policies, as well as in all areas of emergency response.  Employees are trained on, use, and apply the guidelines of our PSM program, which include all of the above-listed areas.  All of these programs come under scheduled scrutiny and critique.
